remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_SampleFormat.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_FMT_U8.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_FMT_S16.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_FMT_S32.

member.name: F:FFMSSharp.SampleFormat.float_t
member.summary: One 32-bit (single precision) floating point value (float_t) per sample

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_FMT_FLT.

member.name: F:FFMSSharp.SampleFormat.double_t
member.summary: One 64-bit (double precision) floating point value (double_t) per sample

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_FMT_DBL.

member.name: T:FFMSSharp.AudioChannels
member.summary: Describes the audio channel layout of an audio stream

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_AudioChannel.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_FRONT_LEFT.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_FRONT_RIGHT.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_FRONT_CENTER.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_LOW_FREQUENCE.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_BACK_LEFT.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_BACK_RIGHT.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_FRONT_LEFT_OF_CENTER.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_FRONT_RIGHT_OF_CENTER.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_BACK_CENTER.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_SIDE_LEFT.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_SIDE_RIGHT.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_TOP_CENTER.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_TOP_FRONT_LEFT.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_TOP_FRONT_CENTER.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_TOP_FRONT_RIGHT.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_TOP_BACK_LEFT.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_TOP_BACK_CENTER.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_TOP_BACK_RIGHT.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_STEREO_LEFT.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CH_STERO_RIGHT.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_AudioSource.
See Index.AudioSource on how to create a AudioSource object.
Note that there is no equivalent for FFMS2's FFMS_GetAudioProperties as it is called during construction of the AudioSource object.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_DestroyAudioSource.

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.AudioSource.GetAudio(System.Int64,System.Int64)
member.summary: Decode a number of audio samples

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_GetAudio.
The output is samples long, starting from (inclusive).

member.param:
The first sample to decode
Sample numbers start from zero and hence the last sample in the stream is number minus 1.

The amount of samples to decode
Sample numbers start from zero and hence the last sample in the stream is number minus 1.
member.exception: Trying to access audio samples that are out of range of the stream.
Trying to start half-way into an unseekable audio stream.

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_AudioProperties->SampleFormat.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.AudioSource.SampleRate
member.summary: Sample rate, in samples per second

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_AudioProperties->SampleRate.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_AudioProperties->BitsPerSample.
Note that this signifies the number of bits actually used to code each sample, not the number of bits used to store each sample, and may hence be different from what the SampleFormat would imply.
Figuring out which bytes are significant and which aren't is left as an exercise for the reader.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_AudioProperties->Channels.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.AudioSource.ChannelLayout
member.summary: The channel layout of the audio stream

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_AudioProperties->ChannelLayout.

Constructed by binary OR'ing the relevant integers from together, which means that if the audio has the channel AudioChannel.Example, the operation (ChannelOrder & AudioChannel.Example) will evaluate to true.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.AudioSource.NumberOfSamples
member.summary: The number of samples in the audio track

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_AudioProperties->NumSamples.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.AudioSource.FirstTime
member.summary: The first timestamp of the stream, in seconds

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_AudioProperties->FirstTime.
Useful if you want to know if the stream has a delay, or for quickly determining its length in seconds.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.AudioSource.LastTime
member.summary: The last timestamp of the stream, in seconds

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_AudioProperties->LastTime.
Useful if you want to know if the stream has a delay, or for quickly determining its length in seconds.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_GetTrackFromAudio.

It's generally safer to use this instead of Index.GetTrack, since unlike that function it cannot cause access violations if you specified an nonexistent track number, return a Track object that doesn't actually contain any indexing information, or return an object that ceases to be valid when the index is destroyed.
Note that the Track object is only valid until its parent AudioSource object is destroyed.

member.name: T:FFMSSharp.ColorSpace
member.summary: Identifies the color coefficients used for a YUV stream

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_ColorSpaces.
The numerical constants are the same as in the MPEG-2 specification.
Some of these are specified or aliased in a number of places.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CS_RGB.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CS_BT709.
Equivalent to ITU-R BT1361, IEC 61966-2-4 xvYCC709 and SMPTE RP177 Annex B.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CS_UNSPECIFIED.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CS_FCC.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CS_BT470BG.
Also known as ITU-T Rec. 601.
Equivalent to ITU-R BT601-6 625, ITU-R BT1358 625, ITU-R BT1700 625 PAL & SECAM and IEC 61966-2-4 xvYCC601.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CS_SMPTE170M.
Functionally the same as BT470BG, and is furthermore equivalent to ITU-R BT601-6 525, ITU-R BT1358 525, and ITU-R BT1700 NTSC.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CS_SMPTE240M.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CS_YCOCG.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_BT2020_NCL.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_BT2020_CL.

member.name: T:FFMSSharp.ColorRange
member.summary: Identifies the valid range of luma values in a YUV stream

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_ColorRanges.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CR_UNSPECIFIED.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CR_MPEG.
Valid luma values range from 16 to 235 with 8-bit color.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CR_JPEG.
All representable luma values are valid.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_Frame.
See VideoSource.GetFrame on how to create a Frame object.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.Frame.Data
member.summary: An array of pointers to the pixel data

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_Frame->Data.
Planar formats use more than one plane, for example YV12 uses one plane each for the Y, U and V data.
Packed formats (such as the various RGB32 flavors) use only the first plane.
If you want to determine if plane i contains data or not, check for [i] != 0.

member.exception: Calling this function after you have called VideoSource.GetFrame, SetInputFormat, ResetInputFormat, SetOutputFormat, ResetOutputFormat, or after the has been destroyed.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.Frame.Linesize
member.summary: An array of integers representing the length of each scan line in each of the four picture planes, in bytes

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_Frame->Linesize.
In alternative terminology, this is the "pitch" of the plane.

Usually, the total size in bytes of picture plane i is [i] * Resolution.Height, but do note that some pixel formats (most notably YV12) has vertical chroma subsampling, and then the U/V planes may be of a different height than the primary plane.
This may be negative; if so the image is stored inverted in memory and Data actually points of the last row of the data.
You usually do not need to worry about this, as it mostly works correctly by default if you're processing the image correctly.

member.exception: Calling this function after you have called VideoSource.GetFrame, SetInputFormat, ResetInputFormat, SetOutputFormat, ResetOutputFormat, or after the has been destroyed.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.Frame.EncodedResolution
member.summary: The original resolution of the frame (in pixels)

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_Frame->EncodedWidth and EncodedHeight.
As encoded in the compressed file, before any scaling was applied.
Note that this must not necessarily be the same for all frames in a stream.

member.exception: Calling this function after you have called VideoSource.GetFrame, SetInputFormat, ResetInputFormat, SetOutputFormat, ResetOutputFormat, or after the has been destroyed.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.Frame.EncodedPixelFormat
member.summary: The original pixel format of the frame

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_Frame->EncodedPixelFormat.
As encoded in the compressed file.

member.exception: Calling this function after you have called VideoSource.GetFrame, SetInputFormat, ResetInputFormat, SetOutputFormat, ResetOutputFormat, or after the has been destroyed.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.Frame.Resolution

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_Frame->ScaledWidth and ScaledHeight.

member.exception: Calling this function after you have called VideoSource.GetFrame, SetInputFormat, ResetInputFormat, SetOutputFormat, ResetOutputFormat, or after the has been destroyed.

The pixel format of what is actually stored in the field.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.Frame.KeyFrame

member.exception: Calling this function after you have called VideoSource.GetFrame, SetInputFormat, ResetInputFormat, SetOutputFormat, ResetOutputFormat, or after the has been destroyed.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.Frame.RepeatPicture
member.summary: An integer representing the RFF flag for this frame

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_Frame->RepeatPict.
The frame shall be displayed for 1+ time units, where the time units are expressed in the special RFF timebase available in and .
Note that if you actually end up using this, you need to ignore the usual timestamps (calculated via the / and the ) since they are fundamentally incompatible with RFF flags.

member.exception: Calling this function after you have called VideoSource.GetFrame, SetInputFormat, ResetInputFormat, SetOutputFormat, ResetOutputFormat, or after the has been destroyed.

member.name: T:FFMSSharp.FrameInfo
member.summary: Information about a single video frame

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_FrameInfo.
See Track.GetFrameInfo on how to create a FrameInfo object.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.FrameInfo.PTS
member.summary: The decoding timestamp of the frame

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_FrameInfo->PTS.
To convert this to a timestamp in wallclock milliseconds, use the relation long timestamp = (long)(( * Track.TimeBase.Numerator) / (double)Track.TimeBase.Denumerator).
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_FrameInfo->RepeatPict.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_FrameInfo->KeyFrame.

member.name: T:FFMSSharp.SeekMode
member.summary: Used to control the way seeking is handled

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_SeekMode.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_SEEK_LINEAR_NO_RW.
Will throw an error if each successive requested frame number isn't bigger than the last one.
Only intended for opening images but might work on well with some obscure video format.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_SEEK_LINEAR.
If you request frame n without having requested frames 0 to n-1 in order first, all frames from 0 to n will have to be decoded before n can be delivered.
The definition of slow, but should make some formats "usable".
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_SEEK_NORMAL.
Bases seeking decisions on the keyframe positions reported by libavformat.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_SEEK_UNSAFE.
Same as but no error will be thrown if the exact destination has to be guessed.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_SEEK_AGGRESSIVE.
Seeks in the forward direction even if no closer keyframe is known to exist.
Only useful for testing and containers where libavformat doesn't report keyframes properly.

member.name: T:FFMSSharp.IndexErrorHandling
member.summary: Used to control behavior when a decoding error is encountered

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_IndexErrorHandling.

member.name: F:FFMSSharp.IndexErrorHandling.Abort
member.summary: Abort indexing and raise an exception

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_IEH_ABORT.

member.name: F:FFMSSharp.IndexErrorHandling.ClearTrack
member.summary: Clear all indexing entries for the track

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_IEH_CLEAR_TRACK.
Returns a blank track.

member.name: F:FFMSSharp.IndexErrorHandling.StopTrack
member.summary: Stop indexing but keep previous indexing entries

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_IEH_STOP_TRACK.
Returns a track that stops where the error occurred.

member.name: F:FFMSSharp.IndexErrorHandling.Ignore
member.summary: Ignore the error and pretend it's raining

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_IEH_IGNORE.

member.name: T:FFMSSharp.AudioDelayMode
member.summary: Controls how audio with a non-zero first PTS is handled

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_AudioDelayModes.
In other words: what FFMS does about audio delay.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_DELAY_NO_SHIFT.
The first decodable audio sample becomes the first sample in the output.
May lead to audio/video desync.

member.name: F:FFMSSharp.AudioDelayMode.TimeZero
member.summary: Samples are created (with silence) or discarded so that sample 0 in the decoded audio starts at time zero

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_DELAY_TIME_ZERO.

member.name: F:FFMSSharp.AudioDelayMode.FirstVideoTrack
member.summary: Samples are created (with silence) or discarded so that sample 0 in the decoded audio starts at the same time as frame 0 of the first video track

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_DELAY_FIRST_VIDEO_TRACK.
This is what most users want and is a sane default.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_Index.
To get an Index for a media file you haven't indexed yet, use the Indexer class.

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.Index.BelongsToFile(System.String)
member.summary: Check if the index belongs to a specific file

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_IndexBelongsToFile.
Makes a heuristic (but very reliable) guess about whether the index is of the or not.

Useful to determine if the index object you just created by loading an index file from disk is actually relevant to your interests, since the only two ways to pair up index files with source files are a) trust the user blindly, or b) comparing the filenames; neither is very reliable.

member.param: File to check against
member.returns: True or false depending on the result

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.Index.VideoSource(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,FFMSSharp.SeekMode)

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CreateVideoSource.

Note that the index object is copied into the VideoSource object upon its creation, so once you've created the video source you can generally destroy the index object immediately, since all info you can retrieve from it is also retrievable from the VideoSource object.

member.param: The media file. Can be an absolute or relative path
Track number of the specific video track

Number of threads used for decoding
Anything less than 1 will use threads equal to the number of CPU cores.
Values >1 have no effect if FFmpeg was not compiled with threading support.

Controls how seeking (random access) is handled and hence affects frame accuracy
Has no effect on Matroska files, where the equivalent of Normal is always used.
LinearNoRw may come in handy if you want to open images.
member.exception: Failure to open the
Trying to make a VideoSource out of an invalid track
Supplying the wrong

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.Index.AudioSource(System.String,System.Int32,FFMSSharp.AudioDelayMode)

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CreateAudioSource.

Note that the index object is copied into the AudioSource object upon its creation, so once you've created the video source you can generally destroy the index object immediately, since all info you can retrieve from it is also retrievable from the AudioSource object.

member.param: The media file. Can be an absolute or relative path
Track number of the specific audio track
Controls how audio with a non-zero first PTS is handled; in other words what FFMS does about audio delay.
member.exception: Failure to open the
Trying to make a AudioSource out of an invalid track
Supplying the wrong

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.Index.GetTrack(System.Int32)

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_GetTrackFromIndex.
Use this function if you don't want to (or cannot) open the track with VideoSource or AudioSource first.
If you already have a VideoSource object or AudioSource object it's safer to use the Track property of VideoSource and AudioSource instead.
The returned Track object is only valid until its parent Index object is destroyed.

Requesting indexing information for a track that has not been indexed will not cause an error, it will just return an empty FFMS_Track (check for >0 frames using GetNumFrames to see if the returned object actually contains indexing information).

member.param: Track number
member.exception: Trying to access a Track that doesn't exist.

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.Indexer.#ctor(System.String,FFMSSharp.Source)
member.summary: Create an indexer of a media file

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_CreateIndexer or FFMS_CreateIndexerWithDemuxer.
The chosen demuxer gets used for both indexing and decoding later on. Only force one if you know what you're doing.
Picking a demuxer that doesn't work on your file will not cause automatic fallback on lavf or automatic probing; it'll just cause indexer creation to fail.

member.param: The media file
What demuxer to use

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_TrackTimeBase and FFMS_GetTimeBase.
Only meaningful for video tracks.

Note that while this rational number may occasionally turn out to be equal to 1/framerate for some CFR video tracks, it really has no relation whatsoever with the video framerate and you should definitely not assume anything framerate-related based on it.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.Track.TimeBaseDenominator
member.summary: The basic time unit of the track

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_TrackTimeBase and FFMS_GetTimeBase.
Only meaningful for video tracks.

Note that while this rational number may occasionally turn out to be equal to 1/framerate for some CFR video tracks, it really has no relation whatsoever with the video framerate and you should definitely not assume anything framerate-related based on it.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_GetTrackType.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.Track.NumberOfFrames
member.summary: The number of frames in the track

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_GetNumFrames.
For a video track this is the number of video frames, for an audio track it's the number of packets.
A return value of 0 indicates the track has not been indexed.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_Resizers.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_RESIZERS_FAST_BILINEAR.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_RESIZERS_BILINEAR.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_RESIZERS_BICUBIC.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_RESIZERS_X.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_RESIZERS_POINT.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_RESIZERS_AREA.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_RESIZERS_BICUBLIN.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_RESIZERS_GAUSS.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_RESIZERS_SINC.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_RESIZERS_LANCZOS.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_RESIZERS_SPLINE.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_VideoSource.
See Index.VideoSource on how to create a VideoSource object.
Note that there is no equivalent for FFMS2's FFMS_GetVideoProperties as it is called during construction of the VideoSource object.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_DestroyVideoSource.

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.SetOutputFormat(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{System.Int32},System.Int32,System.Int32,FFMSSharp.Resizer)
member.summary: Sets the output format for video frames

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_SetOutputFormatV2.

member.param:
The desired output colorspace(s)
The destination that gives the least lossy conversion from the source colorspace will automatically be selected, ON A FRAME BASIS.
To get the integer constant representing a given colorspace, see GetPixFmt.

The desired image width, in pixels
If you do not want to resize just pass the input dimensions.

The desired image height, in pixels
If you do not want to resize just pass the input dimensions.

The desired image resizing algorithm.
You must choose one even if you're not actually rescaling the image, because the video may change resolution mid-stream and then you will be using a resizer whether you want it or not (you will only know that the resolution changed after you actually decoded a frame with a new resolution), and it may also get used for rescaling subsampled chroma planes.
member.exception: Trying to set the desired image resolution to an invalid size like 0, 0.
Trying to supply a null list of .
Trying to set an invalid output format.

param.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_ResetOutputFormatV.
Resets the output format so that no conversion takes place.
Note that the results of this function may vary wildly, particularly if the video changes resolution mid-stream.
If you call it, you'd better call GetFrame afterwards and examine the properties to see what you actually ended up with.

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.SetInputFormat(FFMSSharp.ColorSpace,FFMSSharp.ColorRange)
member.summary: Override the source format for video frames

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_SetInputFormatV.
Override the source colorspace passed to SWScale for conversions and resizing for all further calls to GetFrame, until the next time you call SetInputFormat or ResetInputFormat.
This is intended primarily for compatibility with programs which use the wrong YUV colorspace when converting to or from RGB, but can also be useful for files which have incorrect colorspace flags.
Values passed are not checked for sanity; if you wish you may tell FFMS2 to pretend that a RGB files is actually YUV using this function, but doing so is unlikely to have useful results.
This function only has an effect if the output format is also set with SetOutputFormat.

member.param: The desired input colorspace
The desired input colorrange
member.exception: Trying to set an invalid output format.

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.SetInputFormat(System.Int32,FFMSSharp.ColorSpace,FFMSSharp.ColorRange)
member.summary: Override the source format for video frames

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_SetInputFormatV.
Override the source colorspace passed to SWScale for conversions and resizing for all further calls to GetFrame, until the next time you call SetInputFormat or ResetInputFormat.
This is intended primarily for compatibility with programs which use the wrong YUV colorspace when converting to or from RGB, but can also be useful for files which have incorrect colorspace flags.
Values passed are not checked for sanity; if you wish you may tell FFMS2 to pretend that a RGB files is actually YUV using this function, but doing so is unlikely to have useful results.
This function only has an effect if the output format is also set with SetOutputFormat.

member.param: The desired input pixel format
The desired input colorspace
The desired input colorrange
member.exception: Trying to set an insane input format.

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.ResetInputFormat
member.summary: Resets the video input format to the values specified in the source file

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_ResetInputFormatV.

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.GetFrame(System.Int32)

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_GetFrame.

The returned frame is owned by the given VideoSource object, and remains valid until the video source is destroyed, a different frame is requested from the video source, or the video source's input or output format is changed.

member.param:
The frame number to get
Frame numbering starts from zero, and hence the first frame is number 0 (not 1) and the last frame is number NumFrames - 1.
member.exception: Trying to access a Frame that doesn't exist.

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.GetFrame(System.Double)
member.summary: Retrieves a video frame at a timestamp

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_GetFrameByTime.

The returned frame is owned by the given VideoSource object, and remains valid until the video source is destroyed, a different frame is requested from the video source, or the video source's input or output format is changed.
Does the exact same thing as GetFrame except instead of giving it a frame number you give it a timestamp in seconds, and it will retrieve the frame that starts closest to that timestamp.
This function exists for the people who are too lazy to build and traverse a mapping between frame numbers and timestamps themselves.

member.param: Timestamp
member.exception: Trying to access a Frame that doesn't exist.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.FPSNumerator
member.summary: The nominal framerate of the track

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_VideoProperties->FPSNumerator.
For Matroska files, this number is based on the average frame duration of all frames, while for everything else it's based on the duration of the first frame.

While it might seem tempting to use these values to extrapolate wallclock timestamps for each frame, you really shouldn't do that since it makes your code unable to handle variable framerate properly.
The ugly reality is that these values are pretty much only useful for informational purposes; they are only somewhat reliable for antiquated containers like AVI.
Normally they should never be used for practical purposes; generate individual frame timestamps from FrameInfo.PTS instead.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.FPSDenominator
member.summary: The nominal framerate of the track

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_VideoProperties->FPSDenominator.
For Matroska files, this number is based on the average frame duration of all frames, while for everything else it's based on the duration of the first frame.

While it might seem tempting to use these values to extrapolate wallclock timestamps for each frame, you really shouldn't do that since it makes your code unable to handle variable framerate properly.
The ugly reality is that these values are pretty much only useful for informational purposes; they are only somewhat reliable for antiquated containers like AVI.
Normally they should never be used for practical purposes; generate individual frame timestamps from FrameInfo.PTS instead.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_VideoProperties->RFFNumerator.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_VideoProperties->RFFDenominator.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.NumberOfFrames
member.summary: The number of frames in the video track

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_VideoProperties->NumFrames.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.SampleAspectRatioNumerator
member.summary: Sample aspect ratio of the video frames

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_VideoProperties->SARNum and SARDen.
Note that this is a metadata setting that you are free to ignore, but if you want the proper display aspect ratio with anamorphic material, you should honor it.
On the other hand, there are situations (like when encoding) where you should probably ignore it because the user expects it to be ignored.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.SampleAspectRatioDenominator
member.summary: Sample aspect ratio of the video frames

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_VideoProperties->SARNum and SARDen.
Note that this is a metadata setting that you are free to ignore, but if you want the proper display aspect ratio with anamorphic material, you should honor it.
On the other hand, there are situations (like when encoding) where you should probably ignore it because the user expects it to be ignored.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.Crop
member.summary: The number of pixels you should crop the frame before displaying it

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_VideoProperties->CropTop, CropBottom, CropLeft and CropRight.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_VideoProperties->TopFieldFirst.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.FirstTime
member.summary: The first timestamp of the stream, in seconds

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_VideoProperties->FirstTime.
Useful if you want to know if the stream has a delay, or for quickly determining its length in seconds.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.VideoSource.LastTime
member.summary: The first timestamp of the stream, in seconds

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_VideoProperties->LastTime.
Useful if you want to know if the stream has a delay, or for quickly determining its length in seconds.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_GetTrackFromVideo.

It's generally safer to use this instead of Index.GetTrack, since unlike that function it cannot cause access violations if you specified an nonexistent track number, return a Track object that doesn't actually contain any indexing information, or return an object that ceases to be valid when the index is destroyed.
Note that the Track object is only valid until its parent AudioSource object is destroyed.

member.name: F:FFMSSharp.AVLogLevel.Panic
member.summary: Something went really wrong and we will crash now

member.name: F:FFMSSharp.AVLogLevel.Fatal
member.summary: Something went wrong and recovery is not possible
member.remarks: For example, no header was found for a format which depends on headers or an illegal combination of parameters is used.

member.name: F:FFMSSharp.AVLogLevel.Error
member.summary: Something went wrong and cannot losslessly be recovered
member.remarks: However, not all future data is affected.

member.name: F:FFMSSharp.AVLogLevel.Warning
member.summary: Something somehow does not look correct
member.remarks: This may or may not lead to problems. An example would be the use of '-vstrict -2'.

member.name: F:FFMSSharp.AVLogLevel.Debug
member.summary: Stuff which is only useful for libav* developers

member.name: T:FFMSSharp.Selection
member.summary: Simple representation of a selection rectangle

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_Init.
Must be called before anything else.
If you can't (or don't want to) place ffms2.dll in the same directory as your .exe, you may specify a path where you store it.

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.FFMS2.IsSourcePresent(FFMSSharp.Source)
member.summary: Is the source compiled in the library?
member.param: The source in question

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.FFMS2.IsSourceEnabled(FFMSSharp.Source)
member.param: The source in question

member.name: M:FFMSSharp.FFMS2.GetPixelFormat(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a colorspace identifier from a colorspace name

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_GetPixFmt.
Translates a given pixel format name to an integer constant representing it, suitable for passing to VideoSource.SetOutputFormat.
This function exists so that you don't have to include a FFmpeg header file in every single program you ever write.
For a list of colorspaces and their names, see libavutil/pixfmt.h.
To get the name of a colorspace, strip the leading PIX_FMT_ and convert the remainder to lowercase.
For example, the name of PIX_FMT_YUV420P is yuv420p.

It is strongly recommended to use this function instead of including pixfmt.h directly, since this function guarantees that you will always get the constant definitions from the version of FFmpeg that FFMS2 was linked against.

member.param: ASCII string identifying the pixel format.
member.exception: Invalid pixel format identifier.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.FFMS2.PresentSources
member.summary: Source modules that the library was compiled with

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_GetPresentSources.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.FFMS2.EnabledSources
member.summary: Source modules that are actually available for use

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_GetEnabledSources.
In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_GetVersion.
You may want to use VersionString if you just want to print the version.

member.name: P:FFMSSharp.FFMS2.VersionString
member.summary: A human-readable version of the FFMS_VERSION constant

remarks.para: In FFMS2, the equivalent is FFMS_GetLogLevel and FFMS_SetLogLevel.
